description: The flash transition at the beginning of the film was originally meant to start the film outside the Harvard Depository in the cold and dark rather than inside in the vault's own cold and dark corridors.
One original idea in Cold Storage was to evoke film production equipment as Alain Resnais did to illustrate our technological extensions of memory.

In addition to a Blackmagic Cinema Camera, Cold Storage also employed a Canon T2i DSLR and a GoPro Hero 3+, both pictured here. The GoPro's size made it adaptable to various riggings like the makeshift one we invented here to capture the forest canopy from below.

description:
Toute la mémoire du monde (All the World's Memory) is a 1956 film set around the organization of the Bibliothèque nationale de France (French National Library). Directed by Alain Resnais. Cinematography by Ghislain Cloquet. Written by Rémo Forlani. 
Narration by Jacques Dumesnil. Score by Maurice Jarre. Music conducted by Georges Delerue.Throughout Cold Storage there are citations and references to this film.
This aerial shot of the Bibliothèque nationale de France (French National Library) was grafted onto the front of the Raymond order picker at the beginning of Cold Storage.
A statue from the Bibliothéque nationale de France (French National Library).
"In addition to books, the Depository’s also used to house certain university records and archives, microform, and other media. Each unit is 36 feet high by 45 feet wide by 192 feet long…"
A look at how a palette was used at the rear of an order picker at the Harvard Depository, back in 1993.
The view down aisle 1, back in 1993.

item_title: Bridging the Border - Transferring HD Materials
description: Allison Goffman explores the threshold at which items enter the Harvard Depository.
Google Earth's perspective on the Harvard Depository.
The music used for the external approach to the French National Library was slowed and modified to underscore the differences of the external approach to the Harvard Depository.
"The roof is also constructed of nonflammable material and the site has been clearcut around its perimeter to avoid the dangers of a forest fire.”

“Situated 25 miles west of Cambridge on the 160 acre Southborough Campus of Harvard University, The Harvard Depository represents an entirely new type of library building. The capital costs of construction are essentially one dollar per volume. The modular design of the facility will allow for up to ten units to be constructed with each unit capable of storing over two million volumes."

“Each business day, Depository couriers pick up material for transfer from client libraries to the Depository. Clients are responsible for barcoding all material to be transferred and for linking the barcode to their own bibliographic or descriptive record."
“Generally, all orders received by 3:30 in the afternoon are delivered by the morning of the next business day. Materials travel in a temperature-controlled, alarmed, and locked van."
First Floor Plan of the Harvard Depository, complete with the Module 7 Addition.

description: Jun Wang catalogues the various enumerations of the Harvard Depository.
The music used here to show the open corridors and decorative statues was slowed and modified to underscore the functional fans and sealed corridors of the Depository.

"The Harvard Depository was first conceived in the mid-1980s as an economical solution to the needs of many Harvard libraries. It is more than an efficient warehouse. It is a true innovation—a new kind of library service center driven by the needs of librarians for more space and a better preservation environment and the concerns of administrators to control costs. As you are about to see, the Depository’s innovative construction and unique mode of operation enable it to do 4 things very well: provide a high level of physical control over materials, establish an ideal climate for paper-based materials and certain non-print media, ensure the rapid retrieval of materials on demand, and control costs associated with traditional library operations."
"Each unit is 36 feet high by 45 feet wide by 192 feet long with over 9,000 square feet of shelving space.” A lot has changed since 1993—the Depository now has over 127,000 square feet of storage.

“Special book tray guides have been developed to protect books from possible damage from the shelving bracing. An innovative integral clip mechanism has been created, which combines the functions of shelf brackets and tray guides.”
“The stack area is windowless and to protect materials from exposure to light, the stacks are illuminated by sodium vapor lamps to about 5 foot-candles.”
Turning order picker.
Turning order picker.
Rising order picker from the perspective of the cab.

Laser scanning in the aisles.  “Using portable scanners, shelvers record the location and tray number for each tray shelved. This step associates the tray barcode with the unique shelf or location barcode. When all trays are shelved, this information is downloaded from the portable scanners into the computer system. As part of quality control, all tray-to-shelf work is checked by someone other than the original shelver.”
Carolyn C. Morrow, Malloy-Rabinowitz Preservation Librarian, outlines the Harvard Depository's preservation advantages.

“The Harvard Depository was designed to provide an optimum preservation environment for the collections. Research has shown that heat, humidity, air pollution, and exposure to ultraviolet light accelerate the deterioration of library materials. The Harvard Depository was designed to minimize these agents of deterioration—protecting materials and prolonging their useful life. Unlike a conventional library building, the design of the Depository eliminates many of the problems associated with controlling the environment. The building materials were chosen for their chemical stability to avoid any interaction with stored materials. The building envelope is heavily insulated and a continuous vapor barrier prevents the migration of humidity when the weather changes rapidly."
Jeffrey Schnapp spotted these markings set in cement at various places in the vault.

(2) Harvard President Charles William Eliot's analogy for the kind of facility to meet the library system's offsite storage needs as stated in 1902.

description: Dark Archive n. (1) A repository whose principal aim is to store materials as a failsafe rather than to provide access. (2) One original objective for the Harvard Depository; though much of its holdings are rarely-circulated materials, it has grown to serve a role as hub among numerous libraries, circulating about 250,000 items each year.

Temperature and humidity are controlled to 50 degrees Fahrenheit and 40% relative humidity for the winter months and 60 degrees Fahrenheit and 50% relative humidity in the summer with a system program to gradually change between winter and summer set points.”

item_title: The American Scene Number 11: Library of Congress (1945)
description: Short documentary film about the Library of Congress that was nominated for an Academy Award in 1946 for Best Documentary, Short Subjects.
location: <iframe src="https://archive.org/embed/TheAmericanSceneNumber11LibraryOfCongress" width="492" height="369" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" allowfullscreen></iframe>

description: A series of intertextual allusions were in orbit throughout the film.
Carrying of a large format book.
Pushing a bookcart. Camera angle behind and to the right.
Pushing a bookcart. Camera angle from in front.
Unwrapping incoming accessions.
Applying a sticker label with a letter and numbers to indicate the shelf the book will occupy. Then the books are loaded on a cart to be shelved.
These static portraitures showing areas of the library for different types of content was alluded to in Cold Storage with worker portraits in areas signifying caution within the warehouse.

This shot is of the ceiling of the Oval Reading Room at the Richelieu Site of the Bibliotheque National de France (French National Library). The towering grandeur was illustrative of Sarah Thomas' point that in the past, libraries were often thought of as monumental "shrines to knowledge."

Every picture is stored, like a museum, as is the case in the medals room in which Louis XIV was among the first collectors. These images were paired with Matthew Sheehy's comment that we need to be asking what all the libraries are storing and ask "what commitment we have to the cultural and scientific heritage of our country."
Like a mausoleum, these items appear almost an interred underground.
The databases of the past weren't as spacially efficient as in the contemporary computer age.
How has the function of a library as civic space changed and how will it continue to change?

Mail couriers to the French National Library against Maurice Jarre's musical nod to "Singing in the Rain." Part of the extended network of systems that constitute libraries as systems storing and circulating periodicals, documents and books.
In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, this shot was constrasted against the exterior of the roof of the Harvard Depository.

In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, this hand-carried accession package to the French National Library is contrasted with the scores of heavy bins the staff must wrangle, usually on mechanized lifts due to sheer volume of materials.
In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, the opening of the paper-wrapped parcel is compared to the opening of the reusable plastic bin.
In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, both the French National Library and the Harvard Depository show their respective style and scale of extensive shelving.
In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, the French National Library shows its winding staircases while the Harvard Depository shows its direct ascent via order picker lift.

In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, the French National Library shows its enclosed rising via elevator while the Harvard Depository shows its open cab ascent via order picker lift.

In the cross-cutting montage beginning at 19:26 in Cold Storage, the French National Library shows a book traveling horizontally via cart, while the Harvard Depository shows an item descending diagonally on a order picker bed.

“Books are sorted by size and stored in specially designed trays and stored at right angles to the 36-inch-deep shelves. The trays are shelved two deep—one behind the other. Using book trays of varying sizes permits higher storage densities because books can be stored not only by height, but also by width."

“When the boxes are unpacked, the barcoded materials from each client are kept separate. Books are measured using a template and put in barcoded book trays according to size. After a physical count is made of the books in each tray, the trays are loaded onto carts and brought to the process station. Here barcode numbers for each tray and the books in it are scanned into the computer system. This initiates the electronic association for each item of the unique client barcode with the unique Depository tray barcode. 

When all of the trays on a cart have been processed, the cart is moved to the expedite station. Again, the barcodes of each tray and books associated with it are scanned into the system. This second scan is compared to the first by the computer system and any discrepancies are brought to the attention of the system operator. 

The warehouse manager keeps a chart of locations in the stack area indicating the shelves occupied by each client’s material. Using this chart, the manager produces location sheets indicating where each tray containing new accessions should be shelved. 

Carts are brought into the warehouse and the trays are loaded onto a Raymond lift. Trays are then shelved according to the location sheets."

“The barcodes of all items to be retrieved are keyed into the computer system, which produces a ‘pick list’ in order of location, saving time during retrieval and making the most efficient use of the Raymond lift.”

“The Depository may experiment with alternative modes of delivery including fax and other electronic forms.” The Depository today offers a "Scan & Deliver" service that allows students, faculty, staff, summer school students and special borrowers to request and obtain electronically scanned portions of certain items from the library collections that are currently on the shelf.

“Since its opening in 1986, use of the Depository continues to expand and grow. A new unit is likely to be constructed every 4-5 years as library storage needs dictate.” In reality, the Depository would open a 3rd and a 4th module in less than 4 years, with five total additional modules (3,4,5,6, & B) within just 10 years of the video’s release. Module 7 would open in 2009.
The Depository had only two modules back in 1993.
Jennifer Mills explores and amplifies the patches of color at the Harvard Depository.
Joyce Liu observes aesthetic relationships at Harvard Depository and presents some ideas for integrating some of her observations into visualizations of data.
This animation tracks accessions from the opening of the Harvard Depository to the present while marking the facility's periodic module additions.
Data on accesssions, circulation, and total items handled.

description: Trays are folded in this space to hold the new accessions. As new accessions are removed from the bins they arrive in, they are held against a rubric that places it in a size class, which has a corresponding tray size. These trays, in turn, are codified with a corresponding colored dot. In this album, we see some red bins that additionally have a paper slip announcing "new" on top. This is because red bins are generally used for materials already in the system, which are outgoing for circulation or returning for refile.

description: Bin n. (1) A box, frame, crib, or enclosed place used for storage. (2) A color-coded plastic container used for van transport to and from the Harvard Depository: a gray bin signifies new contents not yet on file; a red bin signifies existing circulating materials in the process of leaving or returning.
location: <object width="492" height="369"> <param name="flashvars" value="offsite=true&lang=en-us&page_show_url=%2Fphotos%2F116285016%40N05%2Fsets%2F72157650246209957%2Fshow%2F&page_show_back_url=%2Fphotos%2F116285016%40N05%2Fsets%2F72157650246209957%2F&set_id=72157650246209957&jump_to="></param> <param name="movie" value="https://www.flickr.com/apps/slideshow/show.swf?v=1811922554"></param> <param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><embed type="application/x-shockwave-flash" src="https://www.flickr.com/apps/slideshow/show.swf?v=1811922554" allowFullScreen="true" flashvars="offsite=true&lang=en-us&page_show_url=%2Fphotos%2F116285016%40N05%2Fsets%2F72157650246209957%2Fshow%2F&page_show_back_url=%2Fphotos%2F116285016%40N05%2Fsets%2F72157650246209957%2F&set_id=72157650246209957&jump_to=" width="492" height="369"></embed></object>

description: Orphan Work n. (1) A copyrighted protected work for which rightsholders are positively indeterminate or uncontactable, yet is not available for legal use by filmmakers, archivists, writers, musicians, or broadcasters. (2) An expanding class of copyrighted items due in part to automatic conferral without registration or renewal and expanded copyright terms. (3) A type of work that Harvard and other institutions have not allowed to be digitized or at least made available to the public, for fear that re-appearing rights holders might sue for damages.

description: How the shot of the camera rising up onto the shelf was achieved.

In contrasting early advertistement of the Depository as "an unlimited resource" with contemporary acknowledgement that the current processes are unsustainable, this Photoshopped image was one of several attempts to imagine the Depository if it continued on its present course of expansion far into the future.
